review.title: Pattern Decomposition with Complex Combinatorial Constraints: Application to Materials Discovery
review.abstract: Identifying important components or factors in large amounts of noisy data is a key problem in machine learning and data mining. Motivated by a pattern decomposition problem in materials discovery, aimed at discovering new materials for renewable energy, e.g. for fuel and solar cells, we introduce CombiFD, a framework for factor based pattern decomposition that allows the incorporation of a-priori knowledge as constraints, including complex combinatorial constraints. In addition, we propose a new pattern decomposition algorithm, called AMIQO, based on solving a sequence of (mixed-integer) quadratic programs. Our approach considerably outperforms the state of the art on the materials discovery problem, scaling to larger datasets and recovering more precise and physically meaningful decompositions. We also show the effectiveness of our approach for enforcing background knowledge on other application domains.

sections.heading: Related work
sections.text: Many low-level alignment programs are available, including QR decomposition, independent component analysis, abbreviated singular value decomposition, and nonnegative matrix factorization (Berry et al. 2007).While these basic methods remain unattended, there is a growing interest in incorporating prior knowledge or user guidance into these frameworks (Zhi et al. 2013).For example, in semi-monitored clustering applications, user guidance is often provided by partial identification information that is incorporated by means of hard limitations (Liu and Wu 2010; Basu, Davidson, and Wagstaff 2008; Choo et al. 2013). Typical limitations used in this case are Must-Link and Cannot-Link, which enforce that two data points must or may not be in the same cluster. For example, (Hossain et al. 2010) we present an integrated framework for clustering non-homogeneous data and show how to consider link-pattern and cannot-link limitations in cluster formation.

sections.heading: Constrained Factorization Algorithm
sections.text: Solving the general CombiFD optimization problem (2) is difficult for two reasons: First, objective function cannot be convex, so minimizing even in the presence of simple non-negative constraints (Berry et al. 2007) is difficult. Second, we allow a very expressive class of constraints that can indicate potentially very complex, complicated dependencies between variables. Unfortunately, most approaches are either application-specific or non-scalable. Even in the presence of simple constraints (as is the case for NMF), the problem is rarely solved and in practice heuristic approaches are used. However, simple heuristic approaches such as multiplicative update rules (Lee and Seung 1999) that are not applied to our problem are used.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: The ability to integrate complex prior knowledge into uncontrolled data analysis approaches is a rich and challenging research problem that is ubiquitous in a variety of areas such as scientific discovery. Specifically, the motivating application of this work is the discovery of new fuel cell and solar fuel materials, thereby solving pressing sustainability issues such as the need for renewable and clean energy. We have introduced CombiFD, a novel factor-based pattern separation framework that significantly generalizes and expands earlier approaches. Our framework allows for the specification of general (including combinatorial) constraints used to define a-primary domain knowledge of desired fragmentation, including traditional constraints such as non-negativity and more complicated dependencies, such as those derived from the known phase behavior of chemical systems. We introduced a generic factoring algorithm called AMIQO, which is based on the solution of a quadratic (sequence) of integrations.
